parsed.raw:
─── SECTION 1: DECOMPOSITION ───

**Sub-questions:**
1. Does VDAC1 gating respond dynamically to physiological Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies (0.1–10 Hz), or is its gating kinetics too slow to track these oscillations?
2. Is VDAC1 oligomerization a frequency-decoded process — does sustained/high-frequency Ca²⁺ loading cross a threshold that triggers oligomeric pore formation (apoptosis), while low-frequency/pulsatile signals maintain monomeric VDAC1 (survival)?
3. How do VDAC1 (OMM) and MCU (IMM) form a coordinated two-gate filter with distinct Ca²⁺ affinity and kinetics?
4. Do cancer cells exploit altered Ca²⁺ oscillation patterns to jam VDAC1 in monomeric/survival mode, complementing HK-II/Bcl-xL/cholesterol mechanisms?

**Key variables:** Ca²⁺ oscillation frequency, VDAC1 gating kinetics (ms-scale), MCU Kd (~10–20 μM), VDAC1 Ca²⁺ permeability, matrix Ca²⁺ accumulation rate, oligomerization threshold [Ca²⁺]m.

─── SECTION 2: CLAIMS ───

CLAIM: VDAC1 gating kinetics (~1–10 ms transitions) are fast enough to partially track Ca²⁺ oscillations at 0.1–1 Hz, but at >5 Hz, VDAC1 effectively time-averages the signal, remaining in a partially open state rather than cycling fully open/closed.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.45
MECHANISM: VDAC1 voltage-dependent gating occurs on ms timescales in bilayers, but cytoplasmic Ca²⁺ oscillations modulate local [Ca²⁺] over 100ms–10s periods, creating frequency-dependent filtering.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Single-channel recordings of VDAC1 in reconstituted membranes exposed to defined Ca²⁺ waveforms at 0.1–10 Hz showing no frequency-dependent gating differences.

CLAIM: VDAC1 oligomerization is driven by cumulative matrix Ca²⁺ overload rather than directly by oscillation frequency — but frequency encodes the *rate* of matrix accumulation, so a frequency threshold (~1–2 Hz sustained) effectively exists above which oligomerization probability sharply increases.
TYPE: 3
CONFIDENCE: 0.35
MECHANISM: High-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses exceed mitochondrial Ca²⁺ efflux capacity (NCLX), causing progressive matrix Ca²⁺ accumulation → mPTP sensitization → VDAC1 oligomerization via conformational changes/cytochrome c release.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Demonstrating that total Ca²⁺ load, not frequency, determines oligomerization when integral is matched across different frequency protocols.

CLAIM: VDAC1-MCU form a two-gate filter where VDAC1 (low selectivity, high conductance, Kd ~0.5 mM) gates bulk Ca²⁺ entry into the IMS, while MCU (high selectivity, Kd ~10–20 μM, cooperative Hill ~3–4) acts as a nonlinear threshold detector — together creating bandpass filtering of Ca²⁺ signals.
TYPE: 1
CONFIDENCE: 0.70
MECHANISM: IMS Ca²⁺ microdomains at VDAC1-MCU contact points reach ~10–20 μM during oscillations, exceeding MCU's activation threshold only during peak phases, creating pulsatile matrix uptake.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Showing IMS [Ca²⁺] at VDAC1-MCU junctions never exceeds MCU Kd during physiological oscillations.

CLAIM: Cancer cells remodel Ca²⁺ oscillation machinery (IP3R, SERCA, STIM/Orai) to reduce oscillation amplitude and increase frequency irregularity, maintaining VDAC1 in monomeric state — this represents a distinct gate-jamming mechanism complementary to HK-II binding.
TYPE: 3
CONFIDENCE: 0.30
MECHANISM: Reduced ER-mitochondria Ca²⁺ transfer (e.g., via Akt-phosphorylated IP3R3, truncated MAM contacts) lowers peak IMS [Ca²⁺], preventing VDAC1 oligomerization threshold.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Comprehensive Ca²⁺ imaging in matched cancer/normal cells showing no systematic difference in mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation parameters.

─── SECTION 3: UNKNOWNS ───

- VDAC1 gating kinetics *in situ* in intact OMM under physiological Ca²⁺

claims.statement: VDAC1 gating kinetics (~1–10 ms transitions) are fast enough to partially track Ca²⁺ oscillations at 0.1–1 Hz, but at >5 Hz, VDAC1 effectively time-averages the signal, remaining in a partially open state rather than cycling fully open/closed.
claims.mechanism: VDAC1 voltage-dependent gating occurs on ms timescales in bilayers, but cytoplasmic Ca²⁺ oscillations modulate local [Ca²⁺] over 100ms–10s periods, creating frequency-dependent filtering.
claims.falsifiable_by: Single-channel recordings of VDAC1 in reconstituted membranes exposed to defined Ca²⁺ waveforms at 0.1–10 Hz showing no frequency-dependent gating differences.

claims.statement: VDAC1 oligomerization is driven by cumulative matrix Ca²⁺ overload rather than directly by oscillation frequency — but frequency encodes the *rate* of matrix accumulation, so a frequency threshold (~1–2 Hz sustained) effectively exists above which oligomerization probability sharply increases.
claims.mechanism: High-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses exceed mitochondrial Ca²⁺ efflux capacity (NCLX), causing progressive matrix Ca²⁺ accumulation → mPTP sensitization → VDAC1 oligomerization via conformational changes/cytochrome c release.
claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that total Ca²⁺ load, not frequency, determines oligomerization when integral is matched across different frequency protocols.

claims.statement: VDAC1-MCU form a two-gate filter where VDAC1 (low selectivity, high conductance, Kd ~0.5 mM) gates bulk Ca²⁺ entry into the IMS, while MCU (high selectivity, Kd ~10–20 μM, cooperative Hill ~3–4) acts as a nonlinear threshold detector — together creating bandpass filtering of Ca²⁺ signals.
claims.mechanism: IMS Ca²⁺ microdomains at VDAC1-MCU contact points reach ~10–20 μM during oscillations, exceeding MCU's activation threshold only during peak phases, creating pulsatile matrix uptake.
claims.falsifiable_by: Showing IMS [Ca²⁺] at VDAC1-MCU junctions never exceeds MCU Kd during physiological oscillations.

claims.statement: Cancer cells remodel Ca²⁺ oscillation machinery (IP3R, SERCA, STIM/Orai) to reduce oscillation amplitude and increase frequency irregularity, maintaining VDAC1 in monomeric state — this represents a distinct gate-jamming mechanism complementary to HK-II binding.
claims.mechanism: complementary to HK-II binding.
claims.falsifiable_by: Comprehensive Ca²⁺ imaging in matched cancer/normal cells showing no systematic difference in mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation parameters. ───

parsed.raw:
─── SECTION 1: DECOMPOSITION ───
**Sub-questions:**
1. Do physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) rhythmically gate VDAC1, producing pulsatile metabolite flux?
2. Does Ca²⁺ transient frequency determine VDAC1 monomer-oligomer equilibrium, with a threshold favoring apoptosis?
3. How do VDAC1 (OMM) and MCU (IMM) coordinate to filter Ca²⁺ signals, and does this create a frequency-dependent "two-gate" system?
4. Do cancer cells exploit altered Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies to lock VDAC1 in a monomeric (pro-survival) state, and can this be therapeutically targeted?

**Key variables:**
- Ca²⁺ oscillation frequency (Hz)
- VDAC1 gating state (open/closed, monomer/oligomer)
- MCU-mediated Ca²⁺ uptake rate
- Metabolite flux (ATP/ADP, ROS, NADH)
- Cell fate (survival/apoptosis)
- Cancer-specific alterations (HK-II, Bcl-xL, cholesterol)

---

─── SECTION 2: CLAIMS ───
**CLAIM:** Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) rhythmically gate VDAC1, producing pulsatile metabolite flux.
**TYPE:** 1 (supported by indirect evidence)
**CONFIDENCE:** 0.7
**MECHANISM:** VDAC1’s voltage-dependent gating is modulated by Ca²⁺ binding (EF-hand-like motifs), causing conformational shifts that transiently open/close the pore in sync with cytosolic Ca²⁺ spikes.
**FALSIFIABLE BY:** Patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in lipid bilayers showing no gating response to 0.1–10 Hz Ca²⁺ pulses, or metabolomics data showing no rhythmic flux of ATP/ADP/ROS.

**CLAIM:** Ca²⁺ transient frequency determines VDAC1 oligomerization state, with a threshold (~1–5 Hz) favoring apoptosis via oligomerization.
**TYPE:** 2 (speculative, mechanism plausible)
**CONFIDENCE:** 0.5
**MECHANISM:** High-frequency Ca²⁺ spikes may saturate VDAC1’s Ca²⁺-binding sites, stabilizing an oligomerization-competent conformation (e.g., via exposure of hydrophobic interfaces), while low-frequency spikes favor monomeric states.
**FALSIFIABLE BY:** FRET or cross-linking assays showing no frequency-dependent oligomerization in isolated mitochondria, or in vivo data where Ca²⁺ clamping at 1–5 Hz fails to induce apoptosis.

**CLAIM:** VDAC1 and MCU act as a "two-gate" Ca²⁺ filter, where VDAC1’s OMM gating sets the amplitude and MCU’s IMM uptake shapes the frequency response.
**TYPE:** 1 (mechanistically coherent)
**CONFIDENCE:** 0.8
**MECHANISM:** VDAC1’s voltage/ligand gating controls Ca²⁺ entry into the intermembrane space, while MCU’s cooperative Ca²⁺ binding (Hill coefficient >1) integrates these signals, filtering low-amplitude/high-frequency noise.
**FALSIFIABLE BY:** Simultaneous Ca²⁺ imaging in cytosol/IMM showing no frequency-dependent attenuation of signals, or MCU knockout failing to disrupt VDAC1-mediated Ca²⁺ oscillations.

**CLAIM:** Cancer cells exhibit altered Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies (e.g., sustained low-frequency spikes) to maintain VDAC1 in a monomeric, pro-survival state, independent of HK-II/Bcl-xL/cholesterol.
**TYPE:** 2 (emerging evidence, not definitive)
**CONFIDENCE:** 0.6
**MECHANISM:** Oncogenic signaling (e.g., PI3K/AKT) may dampen IP₃R-mediated Ca²⁺ release, reducing oscillation frequency and locking VDAC1 in a monomeric state that supports Warburg metabolism.
**FALSIFIABLE BY:** Single-cell Ca²⁺ imaging in cancer vs. normal cells showing no frequency differences, or VDAC1 oligomerization assays in cancer cells showing no correlation with oscillation frequency.

**CLAIM:** Pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetics or pharmacological modulators) can shift VDAC1 toward oligomerization and apoptosis in cancer, with a therapeutic index >10.
**TYPE:** 3 (high-risk, high-reward)
**CONFIDENCE:** 0.4
**MECHANISM:** Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ transients (e.g., 5 Hz) may override cancer’s endogenous low-frequency signals, inducing VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
**FALSIFIABLE BY:** In vivo models showing no apoptosis induction at therapeutic doses, or off-target toxicity (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias) at <10x effective dose.

---

─── SECTION 3: UNKNOWNS ───
1. **Direct evidence of VDAC1 gating by Ca²⁺ oscillations:** No single-channel recordings under physiological Ca²⁺ pulse trains (0.1–10 Hz) exist.
2. **Frequency threshold for oligomerization:** No quantitative data on how Ca²⁺ spike frequency maps to VDAC1 monomer/oligomer ratios.
3. **Cancer-specific oscillation signatures:** Limited comparative Ca²⁺ imaging datasets (cancer vs. normal) across multiple cell lines.
4

claims.statement: Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) rhythmically gate VDAC1, producing pulsatile metabolite flux.
claims.mechanism: VDAC1’s voltage-dependent gating is modulated by Ca²⁺ binding (EF-hand-like motifs), causing conformational shifts that transiently open/close the pore in sync with cytosolic Ca²⁺ spikes.
claims.falsifiable_by: Patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in lipid bilayers showing no gating response to 0.1–10 Hz Ca²⁺ pulses, or metabolomics data showing no rhythmic flux of ATP/ADP/ROS.

claims.mechanism: plausible)
claims.falsifiable_by: FRET or cross-linking assays showing no frequency-dependent oligomerization in isolated mitochondria, or in vivo data where Ca²⁺ clamping at 1–5 Hz fails to induce apoptosis.

claims.mechanism: VDAC1’s voltage/ligand gating controls Ca²⁺ entry into the intermembrane space, while MCU’s cooperative Ca²⁺ binding (Hill coefficient >1) integrates these signals, filtering low-amplitude/high-frequency noise.
claims.falsifiable_by: Simultaneous Ca²⁺ imaging in cytosol/IMM showing no frequency-dependent attenuation of signals, or MCU knockout failing to disrupt VDAC1-mediated Ca²⁺ oscillations.

claims.statement: Cancer cells exhibit altered Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies (e.g., sustained low-frequency spikes) to maintain VDAC1 in a monomeric, pro-survival state, independent of HK-II/Bcl-xL/cholesterol.
claims.mechanism: Oncogenic signaling (e.g., PI3K/AKT) may dampen IP₃R-mediated Ca²⁺ release, reducing oscillation frequency and locking VDAC1 in a monomeric state that supports Warburg metabolism.
claims.falsifiable_by: Single-cell Ca²⁺ imaging in cancer vs. normal cells showing no frequency differences, or VDAC1 oligomerization assays in cancer cells showing no correlation with oscillation frequency.

claims.statement: Pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetics or pharmacological modulators) can shift VDAC1 toward oligomerization and apoptosis in cancer, with a therapeutic index >10.
claims.mechanism: Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ transients (e.g., 5 Hz) may override cancer’s endogenous low-frequency signals, inducing VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
claims.falsifiable_by: In vivo models showing no apoptosis induction at therapeutic doses, or off-target toxicity (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias) at <10x effective dose. --- ───

parsed.raw:
─── SECTION 1: DECOMPOSITION (max 200 tokens) ───
Sub-questions:
(1) Do physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1-10 Hz) rhythmically gate VDAC1, enabling pulsatile metabolite flux?
(2) Does Ca²⁺ oscillation frequency dictate VDAC1 monomeric (survival) vs. oligomeric (death) state, via a threshold?
(3) How do VDAC1 (OMM) and MCU (IMM) form a two-gate Ca²⁺ filter?
(4) In cancer, do altered Ca²⁺ frequencies maintain VDAC1 monomeric state (beyond HK-II/Bcl-xL)? Is frequency pacing therapeutic?

Key variables: Ca²⁺ freq. (f, 0.1-10 Hz), VDAC1 P_open (gated by [Ca²⁺]_IMS, voltage), oligomer state (mono f< thresh → survival; oligo f> thresh → death), MCU flux (V_max ~ [Ca²⁺]_IMS), metabolite flux (pulsatile ∝ P_open), cell fate.
Relationships: f → [Ca²⁺]_cyto → VDAC1 gating → [Ca²⁺]_IMS → MCU uptake → matrix [Ca²⁺] → VDAC1 oligo threshold.

─── SECTION 2: CLAIMS (max 400 tokens) ───
CLAIM: VDAC1 is Ca²⁺-permeable and its conductance is modulated by physiological [Ca²⁺] (μM range), but gating kinetics (~ms) allow rhythmic response to 0.1-10 Hz oscillations, creating pulsatile IMS Ca²⁺/metabolite flux.
TYPE: 1
CONFIDENCE: 0.85
MECHANISM: Ca²⁺ binds VDAC1 C-terminus, stabilizing open state at low [Ca²⁺] and promoting closure/flux modulation at peaks.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Patch-clamp on isolated mito showing no P_open oscillation at 0.1-10 Hz sinusoidal [Ca²⁺]_ext.

CLAIM: High-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations (>1-2 Hz) promote VDAC1 oligomerization (pro-death) vs. low-frequency (<0.5 Hz, survival) via sustained IMS/matrix Ca²⁺ overload, with ~1 Hz threshold.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.65
MECHANISM: Freq-dependent MCU rectification amplifies matrix Ca²⁺ at high f, triggering ROS/PTP that stabilizes VDAC1 oligomers.
FALSIFIABLE BY: VDAC1 oligomer assays (BN-PAGE) in MCU-KO cells showing no freq-dependent shift.

CLAIM: VDAC1/MCU form a two-gate filter: VDAC1 permits cytosolic Ca²⁺ bursts to IMS (rate-limited by voltage/Ca²⁺ gating); MCU rectifies high-freq bursts for matrix uptake (K_d ~1-20 μM, Hill n>1).
TYPE: 1
CONFIDENCE: 0.9
MECHANISM: Spatial proximity (~10 nm) and MICU1/2 sensing ensure MCU activates only at peak [Ca²⁺]_IMS >5 μM from VDAC1.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Super-res EM or FRAP showing no VDAC1-MCU co-localization/flux coupling.

CLAIM: Cancer cells exhibit lower Ca²⁺ oscillation freq. (0.1-0.5 Hz vs. 1-5 Hz normal), stabilizing monomeric VDAC1, additive to HK-II/Bcl-xL jamming.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.6
MECHANISM: Upregulated PMCA/SERCA pumps dampen freq., preventing Ca²⁺ overload-induced oligomerization.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Live-cell imaging in matched normal/cancer lines showing no freq. difference.

CLAIM: Pacing mito Ca²⁺ uptake freq. (>2 Hz) is viable therapeutic target to oligomerize VDAC1 in cancer (safety index >10 if selective), superior to CBD (Kd=11 μM, window 1-10 μM but CYP3A4 IC50=1 μM).
TYPE: 3
CONFIDENCE: 0.4
MECHANISM: Opto/genetic MCU pacing (e.g., opto-MCU) forces high-freq uptake, bypassing cancer-damped signals.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Freq.-paced MCF7 cells (dox IC50=0.5 μM benchmark) showing no apoptosis shift vs. vehicle.

─── SECTION 3: UNKNOWNS (max 150 tokens) ───
Precise VDAC1 Ca²⁺ dose-response for oligomerization (no direct Kd/IC50). Freq. threshold validated in vivo (human tissue imaging). Quantitative model of VDAC1-MCU Ca²⁺ flux coupling (no rate constants). Cancer-specific freq. distributions (primary vs. cell lines). CBD competition with Ca²⁺ on VDAC1 (binding site overlap?). No head-to-head TI data for freq. pacing vs. dox/CBD.

─── SECTION 4: NEXT STEP (max 50 tokens) ───
High-content imaging: CRISPR VDAC1-GFP in MCF7; impose 0.1-10 Hz Ca²⁺ optogenetics; quantify oligomerization (FRET) vs. apoptosis.

claims.statement: VDAC1 is Ca²⁺-permeable and its conductance is modulated by physiological [Ca²⁺] (μM range), but gating kinetics (~ms) allow rhythmic response to 0.1-10 Hz oscillations, creating pulsatile IMS Ca²⁺/metabolite flux.
claims.mechanism: Ca²⁺ binds VDAC1 C-terminus, stabilizing open state at low [Ca²⁺] and promoting closure/flux modulation at peaks.
claims.falsifiable_by: Patch-clamp on isolated mito showing no P_open oscillation at 0.1-10 Hz sinusoidal [Ca²⁺]_ext.

claims.statement: High-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations (>1-2 Hz) promote VDAC1 oligomerization (pro-death) vs. low-frequency (<0.5 Hz, survival) via sustained IMS/matrix Ca²⁺ overload, with ~1 Hz threshold.
claims.mechanism: Freq-dependent MCU rectification amplifies matrix Ca²⁺ at high f, triggering ROS/PTP that stabilizes VDAC1 oligomers.
claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 oligomer assays (BN-PAGE) in MCU-KO cells showing no freq-dependent shift.

claims.statement: VDAC1/MCU form a two-gate filter: VDAC1 permits cytosolic Ca²⁺ bursts to IMS (rate-limited by voltage/Ca²⁺ gating); MCU rectifies high-freq bursts for matrix uptake (K_d ~1-20 μM, Hill n>1).
claims.mechanism: Spatial proximity (~10 nm) and MICU1/2 sensing ensure MCU activates only at peak [Ca²⁺]_IMS >5 μM from VDAC1.
claims.falsifiable_by: Super-res EM or FRAP showing no VDAC1-MCU co-localization/flux coupling.

claims.statement: Cancer cells exhibit lower Ca²⁺ oscillation freq. (0.1-0.5 Hz vs. 1-5 Hz normal), stabilizing monomeric VDAC1, additive to HK-II/Bcl-xL jamming.
claims.mechanism: Upregulated PMCA/SERCA pumps dampen freq., preventing Ca²⁺ overload-induced oligomerization.
claims.falsifiable_by: Live-cell imaging in matched normal/cancer lines showing no freq. difference.

claims.statement: Pacing mito Ca²⁺ uptake freq. (>2 Hz) is viable therapeutic target to oligomerize VDAC1 in cancer (safety index >10 if selective), superior to CBD (Kd=11 μM, window 1-10 μM but CYP3A4 IC50=1 μM).
claims.mechanism: Opto/genetic MCU pacing (e.g., opto-MCU) forces high-freq uptake, bypassing cancer-damped signals.
claims.falsifiable_by: Freq.-paced MCF7 cells (dox IC50=0.5 μM benchmark) showing no apoptosis shift vs. vehicle. ───

parsed.raw:
─── SECTION 1: DECOMPOSITION (max 200 tokens) ───
1.  What are the kinetics of VDAC1 gating in response to transient, localized calcium influx, and can the channel's open probability track physiological oscillation frequencies (0.1-10 Hz)?
2.  Is there a frequency-dependent threshold for calcium signals that determines whether VDAC1 conformational changes are transient (pro-survival) or accumulate to trigger stable oligomerization (pro-apoptotic)?
3.  Do cancer cells suppress high-frequency mitochondrial calcium transients as a dynamic gate-jamming mechanism to prevent VDAC1-mediated apoptosis?

Key variables:
*   **Independent:** Cytosolic Ca2+ oscillation frequency (Hz) and amplitude (µM).
*   **Dependent:** VDAC1 open probability (Pₒ), VDAC1 oligomerization state, mitochondrial metabolite flux, and apoptotic signaling activation.
*   **Mediating:** Outer mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨₒₘₘ), MCU uptake rate, intermembrane space [Ca2+].

─── SECTION 2: CLAIMS (max 400 tokens) ───
CLAIM: VDAC1 gating is fast enough to follow physiological calcium oscillations, creating a pulsatile flux of both Ca2+ and metabolites across the outer mitochondrial membrane.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.9
MECHANISM: The rapid influx of Ca2+ ions through the VDAC1 pore alters the local transmembrane potential, and since VDAC1's voltage-gating operates on a millisecond timescale, it can rhythmically open and close in sync with sub-10 Hz signals.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Single-channel patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in a reconstituted lipid bilayer showing no change in open probability (Pₒ) when exposed to oscillating calcium gradients at 1-10 Hz.

CLAIM: A sustained, high-frequency (>1 Hz) mitochondrial Ca2+ signal is required to trigger VDAC1 oligomerization, while low-frequency (<0.1 Hz) signals permit relaxation to the monomeric state.
TYPE: 3
CONFIDENCE: 0.7
MECHANISM: High-frequency pulses cause cumulative, incomplete conformational relaxation in VDAC1 monomers, progressively exposing interaction domains that lead to irreversible oligomerization and pore formation.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Super-resolution microscopy (dSTORM/PALM) of mitochondria showing VDAC1 oligomerization is dependent only on the integrated Ca2+ load (total concentration over time), not the signal frequency.

CLAIM: The coordination of low-affinity VDAC1 and high-affinity MCU creates a band-pass filter, allowing mitochondria to respond to large, rapid Ca2+ spikes while ignoring small, slow fluctuations.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.85
MECHANISM: VDAC1 passes high-amplitude Ca2+ signals into the intermembrane space, creating a localized pool that is then efficiently taken up by the high-affinity MCU, effectively filtering for salient signals.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Direct measurement of intermembrane space Ca2+ showing its concentration profile is a simple, non-filtered reflection of cytosolic Ca2+ dynamics.

─── SECTION 3: UNKNOWNS (max 150 tokens) ───
The most critical unknown is the in-situ relaxation time of a VDAC1 monomer after a single calcium-induced conformational shift. We do not know if this relaxation takes milliseconds or seconds in a native membrane environment, which is the key parameter determining the frequency threshold for cumulative effects. Additionally, the precise stoichiometry and stability of VDAC1 oligomers (dimers vs. hexamers) as a function of Ca2+ signal duration and frequency are unknown. We lack data on the specific Ca2+ oscillation frequencies prevalent in various cancer subtypes versus healthy tissue.

─── SECTION 4: NEXT STEP (max 50 tokens) ───
Use optogenetics to pace cytosolic Ca2+ oscillations at varying frequencies (0.01-10 Hz) in live cells, and use super-resolution microscopy to quantify the corresponding VDAC1 oligomerization state in real-time.

claims.statement: VDAC1 gating is fast enough to follow physiological calcium oscillations, creating a pulsatile flux of both Ca2+ and metabolites across the outer mitochondrial membrane.
claims.mechanism: The rapid influx of Ca2+ ions through the VDAC1 pore alters the local transmembrane potential, and since VDAC1's voltage-gating operates on a millisecond timescale, it can rhythmically open and close in sync with sub-10 Hz signals.
claims.falsifiable_by: Single-channel patch-clamp recordings of VDAC1 in a reconstituted lipid bilayer showing no change in open probability (Pₒ) when exposed to oscillating calcium gradients at 1-10 Hz.

claims.statement: A sustained, high-frequency (>1 Hz) mitochondrial Ca2+ signal is required to trigger VDAC1 oligomerization, while low-frequency (<0.1 Hz) signals permit relaxation to the monomeric state.
claims.mechanism: High-frequency pulses cause cumulative, incomplete conformational relaxation in VDAC1 monomers, progressively exposing interaction domains that lead to irreversible oligomerization and pore formation.
claims.falsifiable_by: Super-resolution microscopy (dSTORM/PALM) of mitochondria showing VDAC1 oligomerization is dependent only on the integrated Ca2+ load (total concentration over time), not the signal frequency.

claims.statement: The coordination of low-affinity VDAC1 and high-affinity MCU creates a band-pass filter, allowing mitochondria to respond to large, rapid Ca2+ spikes while ignoring small, slow fluctuations.
claims.mechanism: VDAC1 passes high-amplitude Ca2+ signals into the intermembrane space, creating a localized pool that is then efficiently taken up by the high-affinity MCU, effectively filtering for salient signals.
claims.falsifiable_by: Direct measurement of intermembrane space Ca2+ showing its concentration profile is a simple, non-filtered reflection of cytosolic Ca2+ dynamics. ───

parsed.raw:
─── SECTION 1: DECOMPOSITION (max 200 tokens) ───
1. **Mechanistic Coupling:** How do cytosolic Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) directly influence VDAC1 gating kinetics and metabolite flux? Key variables: Ca²⁺ concentration, oscillation frequency, VDAC1 open probability, ATP/ADP flux.
2. **Fate Decision:** Does Ca²⁺ oscillation frequency determine VDAC1 oligomerization state (monomer vs. oligomer) and thereby cell fate? Key variables: frequency threshold, oligomerization kinetics, apoptosis induction.
3. **System Coordination:** How do MCU (IMM) and VDAC1 (OMM) kinetics interact to create a frequency-filtered Ca²⁺ signal into the matrix? Key variables: MCU activation rate, mitochondrial Ca²⁺ buffering, inter-membrane coupling.
4. **Pathological Dysregulation:** Do cancer cells exhibit specific Ca²⁺ oscillation signatures that favor monomeric VDAC1, contributing to apoptosis resistance alongside known binding partners?
5. **Therapeutic Translation:** Can external pacing of Ca²⁺ oscillations be used to force VDAC1 oligomerization and restore apoptosis in cancer cells?

─── SECTION 2: CLAIMS (max 400 tokens) ───
CLAIM: Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) can rhythmically modulate VDAC1 gating, creating pulsatile metabolite flux.
TYPE: 1
CONFIDENCE: 0.7
MECHANISM: Cytosolic Ca²⁺ binds to VDAC1, altering its voltage-dependent gating kinetics on a timescale matching oscillation periods.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Direct patch-clamp of VDAC1 in intact mitochondria showing no change in open probability when challenged with physiological-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses.

CLAIM: A high-frequency threshold of mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake promotes VDAC1 oligomerization and apoptosis.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.6
MECHANISM: Sustained high-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses cause localized OMM lipid peroxidation or conformational strain, driving VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Demonstrating that forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations do not increase VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis in cells lacking MCU.

CLAIM: Cancer cells can evade apoptosis by maintaining Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies below the VDAC1 oligomerization threshold.
TYPE: 2
CONFIDENCE: 0.65
MECHANISM: Altered ER-mitochondria coupling or upregulated Ca²⁺ buffers limit mitochondrial Ca²⁺ transient frequency, keeping VDAC1 monomeric and non-apoptotic.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Showing that cancer cells with known apoptosis resistance have higher, not lower, mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies.

CLAIM: Therapeutically pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetic MCU) can shift VDAC1 to an oligomeric, pro-apoptotic state.
TYPE: 3
CONFIDENCE: 0.5
MECHANISM: Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ entry via MCU creates a local OMM microenvironment that favors VDAC1-VDAC1 interactions.
FALSIFIABLE BY: Pacing fails to induce VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis even when combined with metabolic stress.

─── SECTION 3: UNKNOWNS (max 150 tokens) ───
1. The direct binding kinetics of Ca²⁺ to VDAC1 at physiological oscillation frequencies are unknown. Missing: stopped-flow or FRET data on Ca²⁺-VDAC1 binding/unbinding rates.
2. The exact lipid/protein microenvironment of VDAC1 in the OMM during high Ca²⁺ flux is unclear. Missing: in situ structural data (e.g., cryo-ET) of VDAC1 arrays under Ca²⁺ pacing.
3. The quantitative relationship between mitochondrial matrix Ca²⁺ transient amplitude/frequency and VDAC1 oligomerization yield is missing. Requires single-cell, simultaneous Ca²⁺ imaging and oligomer detection.
4. Whether cancer cell lines show systematic differences in mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies compared to non-transformed cells is not comprehensively mapped.

─── SECTION 4: NEXT STEP (max 50 tokens) ───
Develop an optogenetic system to pace MCU-mediated Ca²⁺ uptake at defined frequencies in live cells and correlate with real-time VDAC1 oligomerization (FRET biosensor) and cell fate.

claims.statement: Physiological Ca²⁺ oscillations (0.1–10 Hz) can rhythmically modulate VDAC1 gating, creating pulsatile metabolite flux.
claims.mechanism: Cytosolic Ca²⁺ binds to VDAC1, altering its voltage-dependent gating kinetics on a timescale matching oscillation periods.
claims.falsifiable_by: Direct patch-clamp of VDAC1 in intact mitochondria showing no change in open probability when challenged with physiological-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses.

claims.statement: A high-frequency threshold of mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake promotes VDAC1 oligomerization and apoptosis.
claims.mechanism: Sustained high-frequency Ca²⁺ pulses cause localized OMM lipid peroxidation or conformational strain, driving VDAC1 oligomerization and cytochrome c release.
claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ oscillations do not increase VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis in cells lacking MCU.

claims.statement: Cancer cells can evade apoptosis by maintaining Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies below the VDAC1 oligomerization threshold.
claims.mechanism: Altered ER-mitochondria coupling or upregulated Ca²⁺ buffers limit mitochondrial Ca²⁺ transient frequency, keeping VDAC1 monomeric and non-apoptotic.
claims.falsifiable_by: Showing that cancer cells with known apoptosis resistance have higher, not lower, mitochondrial Ca²⁺ oscillation frequencies.

claims.statement: Therapeutically pacing mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uptake (e.g., via optogenetic MCU) can shift VDAC1 to an oligomeric, pro-apoptotic state.
claims.mechanism: Forced high-frequency Ca²⁺ entry via MCU creates a local OMM microenvironment that favors VDAC1-VDAC1 interactions.
claims.falsifiable_by: Pacing fails to induce VDAC1 oligomers or apoptosis even when combined with metabolic stress. ───
